posts.name: Çağan
posts.cooked: How do limelight and heading lock work together and who are the teams that use them?

Quick clairifacation unless I’m missing something, by “heading lock” do you mean the robot always keeps itself pointing towards the last commanded heading from the controller? Or maybe keeping itself pointed at a certain visual target from the Limelight?

posts.name: Çağan
posts.cooked: I hope this doesn’t sound ridiculous but both

posts.name: Mete
posts.cooked: Problably means by having a Motor (ex. Shooter) locked onto a tag like an AprilTag.

Myth:

I hope this doesn’t sound ridiculous but both

Nope, not ridiculous!

Undefined:

Problably means by having a Motor (ex. Shooter) locked onto a tag like an AprilTag.

Going off of this assumption, like if you have a moving mechanism (like a turret or a shooter that can go up and down) with a Limelight camera mounted on it, then you can pull the data from the Limelight and use PID controllers to move the mechanism to your desired location. Our team hasn’t used this on any subsystems, though we have used a very similar concept to aim the entire robot towards a desired visual target.

posts.name: Mete
posts.cooked: We are looking forward to do something like that next year. I am interested about the concept you guys designed, could you explain it to me? Maybe we’ll do something similar to that.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
Myth:

How do limelight and heading lock work together

What are you specifically trying to accomplish?  If you are using a swerve chassis, heading is an ambiguous term.  Heading could refer to the direction of the velocity vector of the robot chassis as it moves across the field or it could be the rotational orientation of the chassis relative to a reference orientation.  I like to distinguish those by calling the first one “heading” and the second one “attitude”, but I don’t think this is a settled convention in FRC .

@SirFire introduces another potential source of ambiguity mentioning a vision solution mounted to a rotating mechanism like a turret.  With that, you would add mechanism attitude (or “heading”) into the mix.

You improve your chances of getting relevant and useful help by being as specific as possible with the question you have.

If you use YAGSL , yoh could use SwerveInputStream which has a function to do this. You can tear apart the class too since its just a Supplier<ChassisSpeeds> anyways.

You just use SwerveInputStream.aim to set the pose it should point at (the apriltag pose). To enable and disable aiming use SwerveInputStream.aimWhile .

Yeah in REEFSCAPE we just had a thing to align to the AprilTags on the REEF. I said “similar concept” because we’re not just piping the Limelight data straight into a PID controller, but rather using two Limelights for AprilTag localization and then using three PID controllers (x, y, and theta) to get the robot to a desired position relative to that AprilTag, or anywhere on the field, for that matter. It worked well because there was an AprilTag right next to where we were aligning to. There are definitely simpler ways to do a similar thing, but that’s how we ended up doing it. (Less reliable if your odometry gets thrown off, as we found xD)

Also, side note @paulonis , you may be totally right, but I don’t really see too much confusion on this topic. In fact, I usually don’t see people using the term “attitude.” “Heading” always seems to refer to simply the direction the robot is pointing. Again, this may very well be an instance of me being mistaken, so please correct me if need be. Also, I do understand the thing about adding more ambiguity with more mechanisms, so yeah I agree that its important to specify.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
SirFire:

I usually don’t see people using the term “attitude.” “Heading” always seems to refer to simply the direction the robot is pointing.

What term do you believe refers to the direction the robot is moving?  With swerve, that direction is independent of the direction the robot is pointing.
i dont think i’ve ever needed a term to refer to the direction of the robot’s velocity vector

This Although technically speaking you’re probably right, but in common discussion, even considering swerve, it seems that “heading” refers to the direction the robot is facing. I don’t remember a time when I’ve needed to refer to the direction the robot is traveling, as @AvocadoPeel mentioned.

In short, since this is off-topic slightly to the OP’s question and I’d like to bring the attention back to that, technically you’re likely correct, but I don’t find it neccesary to raise concern over ambiguity in this context, although I agree that detail is absolutely important.
posts.edit_reason: Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.

posts.cooked: Another approach we (and many other teams) used that I didn’t see mentioned in this thread, is using the pigeon for heading lock to a reef face and then the limelight reading to feed a translational PID perpendicular to the reef pole
